{{distinguish|suprematism}} {{discrimination sidebar}}
'''Supremacism''' is the belief that a particular [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[religion]], [[gender]], [[sexual orientation]], [[Belief|belief system]] or [[culture]] is superior to others and entitles those who identify with it to dominate, control or rule those who do not.
== Sexual ==
Many anthropologists consider male supremacism, also known as “male dominance” or “[[patriarchy]]”, to exist in all cultures throughout human history. Under it special rights or status is granted to men, i.e. "[[male privilege]]." Such supremacy is enforced through a variety of cultural, political and interpersonal strategies.<ref>Peggy Reeves Sanday, ''Female power and male dominance: on the origins of sexual inequality,'' Cambridge University Press, 1981, [http://books.google.com/books?id=39ScGl-T3J0C&pg=PA1&dq=%22male+dominance%22++%22male+supremacism%22&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=8#v=onepage&q=%22male%20supremacism%22&f=false p. 6-8, 113-114, 174, 182]. ISBN 0521280753, 9780521280754</ref> Others note that this often has been balanced by various forms of female authority.<ref>Peggy Reeves Sanday, p. 113.</ref> Since the 19th century there have been a number of [[feminist]] movements opposed to male supremacism and working for equal legal rights and protections for women in all cultural, political and interpersonal relations.<ref>{{cite book |author= |title=Collins Dictionary and Thesaurus |year=2006 |publisher=Collins |location=London |isbn=0-00-722405-2 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Humm, Maggie |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Modern feminisms: Political, Literary, Cultural |year=1992 |publisher=Columbia University Press |location=New York |isbn=0-231-08072-7 |pages=}}</ref><ref name=Cornell>{{cite book |author=Cornell, Drucilla |authorlink=Drucilla Cornell|title=At the heart of freedom: feminism, sex, and equality |year=1998 |publisher=Princeton University Press |location=Princeton, N.J. |isbn=978-0-691-02896-5 }}</ref>
==Racial== The [[Middle Ages]] [[Crusades]] have been described as an example of white supremacist colonialism.<ref>Angeliki E. Laiou, Roy P. Mottahedeh, ''The Crusades from the perspective of Byzantium and the Muslim world'', Dumbarton Oaks, 2001, [http://books.google.com/books?id=YTAhPw3SjxIC&pg=PA3&dq=christian+supremacism+crusades&hl=en&ei=HjSNTK3pAcOB8gb9l6yZCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 3], ISBN 0884022773, 9780884022770</ref> Centuries of European colonialism of the Americas, Africa and Asia was excused by [[White supremacism|white supremacist]] attitudes.<ref>Takashi Fujitani, Geoffrey Miles White, Lisa Yoneyama, [http://books.google.com/books?id=Ltm9hv0_4A0C&pg=PA303&dq=white+european+supremacism+colonialism&ei=9uFcS_awL6a8zgS9q7SMCw&cd=1#v=onepage&q=white%20european%20supremacism%20colonialism&f=false ''Perilous memories: the Asia-Pacific War(s)'']‎, p. 303, 2001.</ref> During the 19th century the phrase "[[The White Man's Burden]]" was widely used to justify imperialist policy as a noble enterprise.<ref>{{cite book | author= Miller, Stuart Creighton| title= Benevolent Assimilation: The American Conquest of the Philippines, 1899-1903 | publisher= Yale University Press | year=1982 | isbn=0-300-03081-9}} p. 5: "...imperialist editors came out in favor of retaining the entire archipelago (using) higher-sounding justifications related to the "white man's burden."</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author= Opinion archive, International Herald Tribune| title=In Our Pages: 100, 75 and 50 Years Ago; 1899: Kipling's Plea | journal=[[International Herald Tribune]] | date=February 4, 1999 | volume= | issue= | pages= 6 | url=http://www.iht.com/articles/1999/02/04/edold.t_10.php }}: Notes that Rudyard Kipling's new poem, "The White Man's Burden," "is regarded as the strongest argument yet published in favor of expansion."</ref>
Following the [[American Civil War]], southern white veterans of the [[Confederate States of America]] formed the secret society known as the [[Ku Klux Klan]] to restore white supremacy after the [[Reconstruction era of the United States|Reconstruction]] period.<ref>Eric Foner, ''Reconstruction: America's Unfinished Revolution, 1863-1877,'' Perennial (HarperCollins), 1989, p. 425-426.</ref> They preached supremacy over all other races, as well as over [[Jew]]s, [[Catholic]]s and other minorities.
[[Black supremacy]] arose in America as a counter to [[white supremacism]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Cornel|last=West|authorlink=Cornel West|year=1993|title=Race Matters|chapter= 8|pages=95–105|publisher=Beacon Press|url=http://www.pragmatism.org/library/west/|isbn=0679749861}}</ref> Groups advocating some version of it include [[Nation of Islam]], the [[New Black Panther Party]], the [[Black Hebrew Israelites]] and the [[Mansions of Rastafari|Bobo Shanti]] section of the [[Rastafari movement]].
During the early 20th century until the end of [[World War II]] - the [[Shōwa era]] - the propaganda of the [[Empire of Japan]] used the old concept of [[hakko ichiu]] to support the idea that the [[Yamato people|Yamato]] was a superior race, destined to rule Asia and the Pacific. Many documents such as ''[[Kokutai no Hongi]]'', ''[[Shinmin no Michi]]'' and ''[[An Investigation of Global Policy with the Yamato Race as Nucleus]]'' referred to this concept of racial supremacy.
During the 1930s and 1940s [[Adolf Hitler]]'s [[Germany|German]] [[Nazism|Nazi]] Party preached the existence of an [[Aryan#Racist connotations|Aryan]] [[master race]] and attempted to establish through conquest such an empire throughout [[Europe]]. They were [[World War II]] "[[Axis powers]]" allies of the Japanese empire.
==Religious==
Some academics and writers describe [[Judaism|Jewish]] supremacism, especially related to [[Israel]] and [[Zionism]]. Author Minna Rozen describes the 17th century Jews of [[Jerusalem]]s’ view of themselves as an elite group among Jews as supremacism.<ref>Minna Rozen, ''[http://books.google.com/books?id=Pt50fMlgKuMC& Jewish identity and society in the seventeenth century: reflections on the life and work of Refael Mordekhai Malki],'' Mohr Siebeck, [http://books.google.com/books?id=Pt50fMlgKuMC&pg=PA129&dq=Jewish+Supremacism&ei=G5IJSri3DIPIyAThjdTfDg& 129], 1992 ISBN 3161457706, 9783161457708</ref> [[Ilan Pappé]] writes that the [[First Aliyah]] to Israel "established a society based on Jewish supremacy."<ref>[[Ilan Pappé]], [http://books.google.com/books?id=JzfgvSiUt9QC The Israel/Palestine question], [http://books.google.com/books?id=JzfgvSiUt9QC&pg=PA89&dq=Jewish+Supremacy&ei=ap0JSqfSH56GyATI4_SRAw 89], 1999 ISBN 041516947X, 9780415169479</ref> [[Joseph Massad]] holds that "Jewish supremacism" always has been a "dominating principle" of religious and secular Zionism.<ref>David Hirsch, [http://www.yale.edu/yiisa/workingpaper/hirsh/David%20Hirsh%20YIISA%20Working%20Paper1.pdf Anti-Zionism and Antisemitism: Cosmopolitan Reflections], The Yale Initiative for the Interdisciplinary Study of Antisemitism Working Paper Series; discussion of [[Joseph Massad]]'s "The Ends of Zionism: Racism and the Palestinian Struggle", Interventions, Volume 5, Number 3, 2003, 440-451, 2003.</ref><ref>According to [[Joseph Massad's [http://www.columbia.edu/cu/mealac/faculty/massad/ "Response to the Ad Hoc Grievance Committee Report1"] on his [[Columbia University]] web site during a 2002 rally he said "Israeli Jews will continue to feel threatened if they persist in supporting Jewish supremacy." Massad notes there that others have misquoted him as saying Israel was a “Jewish supremacist and racist state.” See for example David Horowitz, ''[http://books.google.com/books?id=CYqZjtVp00AC& The professors: the 101 most dangerous academics in America],'' Regnery Publishing, [http://books.google.com/books?id=CYqZjtVp00AC&pg=PA271&dq=“Jewish+supremacist+and+racist+state”&num=100&ei=N6UJSuDoCYPuzQSs5MXyBw& 271], 2006</ref> [[Gilad Atzmon]] labels the ideology he calls “Jewishness” as "very much a supremacist, racist tendency."<ref>Jim Gilchrest interview with [[Gilad Atzmon]], [http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/features/39I-thought-music-could-heal.3804991.jp?CommentPage=1&CommentPageLength=1000 I thought music could heal the wounds of the past. I may have got that wrong], [[The Scotsman]], 22 February 2008; in [http://palestinethinktank.com/2009/03/30/gilad-atzmon-lexicon-of-resistance/ Lexicon of Resistance] Gilad Atzmon explains his views on Jewish ideology and Jewish supremacism.</ref> The [[Anti-Defamation League]] condemns as "[[antisemitic]]" writings about “Jewish Supremacism” by authors [[David Duke]] and [[Kevin MacDonald]].<ref>[http://www.adl.org/learn/ext_us/david_duke/ideology.asp?LEARN_Cat=Extremism&LEARN_SubCat=Extremism_in_America&xpicked=2&item=david_duke David Duke article] and [http://www.adl.org/learn/ext_us/kevin_macdonald/ideology.asp?LEARN_Cat=Extremism&LEARN_SubCat=Extremism_in_America&xpicked=2&item=kevin_macdonald Kevin MacDonald article] at [[Anti-Defamation League]] website.</ref>
Academics and writers have described [[Christian]] supremacism as a motivation for the [[Crusades]] to the “[[Holy Land]],” as well as for crusades against [[Muslim]]s and [[pagan]]s throughout Europe.<ref>Carol Lansing, Edward D. English, ''A companion to the medieval world,'' Volume 7, John Wiley and Sons, 2009, [http://books.google.com/books?id=ecpGCF8-XCkC&pg=PA457&dq=christian+supremacism+crusades&hl=en&ei=2QSMTOCgJ8P78Ab88Py2CQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=christian%20supremacism%20crusades&f=false p. 457], ISBN 140510922X, 9781405109222</ref> The [[Atlantic slave trade]] has been attributed in part to it as well.<ref>Mary E. Hunt, Diann L. Neu, ''New Feminist Christianity: Many Voices, Many Views,'' SkyLight Paths Publishing, 2010, [http://books.google.com/books?id=HxU8716h2VgC&pg=PA122&dq=christian+supremacism&hl=en&ei=vjaMTM7JHYP88AbVkeSQCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 122], ISBN 159473285X, 9781594732850</ref> The [[Ku Klux Klan]] has been described as a Christian, as well as a white, supremacist group.<ref>Jerry Carrier, ''The Making of the Slave Class,'' Algora Publishing, 2010, [http://books.google.com/books?id=P0r2yfJItskC&pg=PA77&dq=christian+supremacism&hl=en&ei=YDSMTPOZGoK88gbdnInbCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 77], ISBN 0875867685, 9780875867687</ref> So are many white supremacist groups in the United States today.<ref>R. Scott Appleby, ''The ambivalence of the sacred: religion, violence, and reconciliation'', Carnegie Commission on Preventing Deadly Conflict series, Rowman & Littlefield, 2000, [http://books.google.com/books?id=8RqbMGvsz5MC&pg=PA103&dq=white+christian+supremacist&hl=en&ei=qz2MTNCcKYT58Aa5nvDmCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCcQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=white%20christian%20supremacist&f=false p. 103], ISBN 0847685551, 9780847685554</ref> President George W. Bush’s support for [[fundamentalist Christianity]] has been linked to his having a “Christian supremacist vision” in his policies in the [[Middle East]].<ref>Nur Masalha, ''The Bible and Zionism: invented traditions, archaeology and post-colonialism in Palestine-Israel'', Volume 1, Zed Books, 2007, [http://books.google.com/books?id=LAUeWo8NDK4C&pg=PA116&dq=christian+supremacism+crusades&hl=en&ei=2QSMTOCgJ8P78Ab88Py2CQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 116], ISBN 1842777610, 9781842777619</ref> Leading executives of [[Blackwater Worldwide]] [[private military company]] have been described as “dedicated to a Christian-supremacist agenda.”<ref>Jeremy Scahill, ''Blackwater: the rise of the world's most powerful mercenary army,'' Nation Books, 2008, [http://books.google.com/books?id=_6f_3DobpdwC&pg=PA61&dq=christian+supremacism+crusades&hl=en&ei=uAiMTJ_sIcL58Aa8o8ykDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 61], ISBN 156858394X, 9781568583945</ref>
Some academics and writers have described evidence of Muslim or [[Islam]]ic supremacism. The [[Qur'an]] and other Islamic documents do allow intolerant interpretations which have been exploited by supremacists.<ref>Joshua Cohen, Ian Lague, Khaled Abou El Fadl, ''The place of tolerance in Islam,'' Beacon Press, 2002, [http://books.google.com/books?id=fMCMR68rNxQC&pg=PA23&dq=islamic+supremacism&hl=en&ei=oRONTNmECMO88ga7kaibDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBzgo#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 23], ISBN 0807002291, 9780807002292</ref> Specific examples include early 20th century “pan-Islamism" promoted by [[Abdul Hamid II]],<ref>Gareth Jenkins, ''Political Islam in Turkey: running west, heading east?,'' Macmillan, 2008, [http://books.google.com/books?id=c8VtheVUlfgC&pg=PA60&dq=muslim+supremacism&hl=en&ei=o0uMTPTGHsG78gbb8-C5CQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=muslim%20supremacism&f=false p. 59], ISBN 1403968837, 9781403968838</ref> the [[jizya]] and rules of marriage in Muslim countries being imposed on non-Muslims<ref>Malise Ruthven, ''Islam: a very short introduction,'' Oxford University Press, 1997, Macmillan, 2008 [http://books.google.com/books?ei=IkyMTPbhFsGB8gbVtZjnCg&ct=result&id=BL_rG9gIq64C&dq=Islamic+supremacism&q=Islamic+supremacism#search_anchor p. 117], ISBN 0199504695, 9780199504695</ref> the majority Muslim interpretations of the rules of pluralism in [[Malaysia]], and "defensive" supremacism practised by some Muslim immigrants in Europe.<ref>Bassam Tibi, [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1754-9469.2010.01038.x/full Ethnicity of Fear? Islamic Migration and the Ethnicization of Islam in Europe], [[John Wiley & Sons]] online, June 2010.</ref> Other writers posit a “poisonous, violent, Islamic supremacist creed”<ref>Mark W. Smith, ''The Official Handbook of the Vast Right-Wing Conspiracy 2008: The Arguments You Need to Defeat the Loony Left This Election Year,'' Regnery Publishing, 2007, [http://books.google.com/books?id=M75_om39mBsC&pg=PA27&dq=islamic+supremacist+conspiracy&hl=en&ei=LBqNTPSTM8H38AaLtMHpCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 27], ISBN 1596980494, 9781596980495</ref> and that supremacism is inherent in Islam.<ref>Robert Spencer, ''Stealth jihad: how radical Islam is subverting America without guns or bombs,'' Regnery Publishing, 2008, [http://books.google.com/books?id=3eLfhvNQBkgC&pg=PA141&dq=islamic+supremacist&hl=en&ei=YxqNTL-QAcP58AaAjY3ECQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=islamic%20supremacism&f=false p. 101, 203, 207], ISBN 1596985569, 9781596985568</ref> [[Bruce Bawer]] alleges that [[Saudi Arabia]]n princes have funded institutions to paint accusations of Islamic supremacism as “[[Islamophobic]] lies.”<ref>Bruce Bawer, ''Surrender: Appeasing Islam, Sacrificing Freedom,'' Random House, Inc., 2007, [http://books.google.com/books?id=1lyNZ9qm7Q4C&pg=PA152&dq=islamic+supremacism&hl=en&ei=ihuNTLbkB8H58Aaf1NHwCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=islamic%20supremacism&f=false p. 152], ISBN 0767928377, 9780767928373</ref>
